data-level="1"><p><strong><span id="ref402117"></span>Soil</strong>,  the biologically active, porous medium that has developed in the uppermost layer of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Earth" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Earth’s</a> crust. <span id="ref709103"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/pedology" class="md-crosslink">Soil</a> is one of the principal substrata of life on Earth, serving as a reservoir of water and nutrients, as a medium for the filtration and breakdown of injurious wastes, and as a participant in the cycling of carbon and other elements through the global <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/ecosystem" class="md-crosslink autoxref">ecosystem</a>. It has evolved through weathering processes driven by biological, climatic, geologic, and topographic influences.</p><!--[P1]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19549"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/66/24266-004-DB5B0A80.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/66/24266-004-DB5B0A80.jpg" alt="Chernozem soil profile from Germany, showing a thick humus-rich surface horizon with a light-coloured lime-rich layer below." data-width="200" data-height="351"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Chernozem soil profile from Germany, showing a thick humus-rich surface horizon with a light-coloured lime-rich layer below.</span><cite>© ISRIC, www.isric.nl</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML1]--><p>Since the rise of agriculture and forestry in the 8th millennium <span class="text-smallcaps">bc</span>, there has also arisen by necessity a practical awareness of soils and their management. In the 18th and 19th centuries the <span id="ref704780"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/event/Industrial-Revolution" class="md-crosslink">Industrial Revolution</a> brought increasing pressure on soil to produce raw materials demanded by commerce, while the development of quantitative science offered new opportunities for improved soil management. The study of soil as a separate scientific <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/discipline" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="discipline">discipline</a> began about the same time with systematic investigations of substances that <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/enhance" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="enhance">enhance</a> plant growth. This initial inquiry has expanded to an understanding of soils as complex, <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/dynamic" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="dynamic">dynamic</a>, biogeochemical systems that are vital to the life cycles of terrestrial vegetation and soil-inhabiting organisms—and by extension to the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/human-being" class="md-crosslink autoxref">human race</a> as well.</p><!--[P2]--><p>This article covers the structure, <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/composition" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="composition">composition</a>, and classification of soils and how these factors affect soil’s role in the global ecosystem. In addition, the two most important phenomena that degrade soils, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/erosion-geology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">erosion</a> and pollution, are discussed. For a cartographic guide to the distribution of the world’s major soils, featuring links to short descriptive entries on each soil type, see the <span data-assembly-id="19523" class="md-link media-overlay-link">interactive world map</span>.</p><!--[P3]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19523"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/40/24240-004-3EACCAD6.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/40/24240-004-3EACCAD6.jpg" alt="Interactive soil map of the world. Click on a continent to see a detailed map of soil regions, with links to articles on specific soils." data-width="525" data-height="348"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Interactive soil map of the world. Click on a continent to see a detailed map of soil regions, with links to articles on specific soils.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML3]--></section><div class="major-reference-upsell">			<iframe src="/GPTIframe/ajax/sync/EB_HOUSE_DESKTOP" scrolling="no" width="640" height="106"></iframe>		</div><section id="ref214834" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">The <span id="ref709100"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/soil-profile" class="md-crosslink">soil profile</a></h2><section id="ref214835" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Soil <span id="ref704781"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/horizon-soil" class="md-crosslink">horizons</a></h2><p>Soils differ widely in their properties because of geologic and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/climate-change" class="md-crosslink autoxref">climatic variation</a> over distance and time. Even a simple property, such as the soil thickness, can <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/rangeland" class="md-crosslink autoxref">range</a> from a few centimetres to many metres, depending on the intensity and duration of <span id="ref709104"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/weathering-geology" class="md-crosslink">weathering</a>, episodes of soil <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/deposition" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="deposition">deposition</a> and erosion, and the patterns of landscape evolution. Nevertheless, in spite of this variability, soils have a unique structural characteristic that distinguishes them from mere earth materials and serves as a basis for their classification: a vertical sequence of layers produced by the combined actions of <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/percolating" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="percolating">percolating</a> waters and living organisms.</p><!--[P4]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19565"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/82/24282-004-04E7D202.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/82/24282-004-04E7D202.jpg" alt="Podzol soil profile from Ireland, showing a bleached layer from which humus and metal oxides have been leached and subsequently deposited in the typically reddish horizon below." data-width="208" data-height="350"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Podzol soil profile from Ireland, showing a bleached layer from which humus and metal oxides have been leached and subsequently deposited in the typically reddish horizon below.</span><cite>© ISRIC, www.isric.nl</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML4]--><p>These layers are called <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/horizon-soil" class="md-crosslink">horizons</a>, and the full vertical sequence of horizons <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/constitutes" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="constitutes">constitutes</a> the soil profile (see the <span data-assembly-id="19380" class="md-link media-overlay-link">figure</span>). Soil horizons are defined by features that reflect soil-forming processes. For instance, the uppermost soil layer (not including surface litter) is termed the <span id="ref705140"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/A-horizon" class="md-crosslink">A horizon</a>. This is a weathered layer that contains an accumulation of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/humus-soil-component" class="md-crosslink">humus</a> (decomposed, dark-coloured, carbon-rich matter) and microbial biomass that is mixed with small-grained minerals to form <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/aggregate" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="aggregate">aggregate</a> structures.</p><!--[P5]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19380"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/19/24019-004-41BFB618.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/19/24019-004-41BFB618.jpg" alt="The soil profile, showing the major layers from the O horizon (organic material) to the R horizon (consolidated rock). A pedon is the smallest unit of land surface that can be used to study the characteristic soil profile of a landscape." data-width="593" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">The soil profile, showing the major layers from the O horizon (organic material) to the R horizon (consolidated rock). A pedon is the smallest unit of land surface that can be used to study the characteristic soil profile of a landscape.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML5]--><p>Below A lies the <span id="ref705160"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/B-horizon" class="md-crosslink">B horizon</a>. In mature soils this layer is characterized by an accumulation of <span id="ref709105"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-mineral" class="md-crosslink">clay</a> (small particles less than 0.002 mm [0.00008 inch] in diameter) that has either been deposited out of percolating waters or precipitated by chemical processes involving dissolved products of weathering. Clay endows B horizons with an array of <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/diverse" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="diverse">diverse</a> structural features (blocks, columns, and prisms) formed from small clay particles that can be linked together in various configurations as the horizon evolves.</p><!--[P6]--><p>Below the A and B horizons is the <span id="ref705182"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/C-horizon" class="md-crosslink">C horizon</a>, a zone of little or no humus accumulation or soil structure development. The C horizon often is composed of unconsolidated parent material from which the A and B horizons have formed. It lacks the characteristic features of the A and B horizons and may be either relatively unweathered or deeply weathered. At some depth below the A, B, and C horizons lies consolidated <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/rock-geology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">rock</a>, which makes up the R horizon.</p><!--[P7]--><p>These simple letter <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/designations" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="designations">designations</a> are supplemented in two ways (see the <span id="ref2860"></span>table of soil horizon letter designations). First, two additional horizons are defined. Litter and decomposed organic matter (for example, plant and animal remains) that typically lie exposed on the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/land-economics" class="md-crosslink autoxref">land</a> surface above the A horizon are given the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/designation" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="designation">designation</a> <span id="ref705200"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/O-horizon" class="md-crosslink">O horizon</a>, whereas the layer immediately below an A horizon that has been extensively <span id="ref705942"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/leaching-geochemistry-of-soil" class="md-crosslink">leached</a> (that is, slowly washed of certain contents by the action of percolating water) is given the separate designation <span id="ref705220"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/E-horizon" class="md-crosslink">E horizon</a>, or zone of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/eluviation" class="md-crosslink autoxref">eluviation</a> (from Latin <em>ex</em>, “out,” and <em>lavere</em>, “to wash”). The development of E horizons is favoured by high rainfall and sandy parent material, two factors that help to ensure extensive water percolation. The solid particles lost through leaching are deposited in the B horizon, which then can be regarded as a zone of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/illuviation" class="md-crosslink autoxref">illuviation</a> (from Latin <em>il</em>, “in,” and <em>lavere</em>).</p><!--[P8]--><span class="md-raw-html"><div class="md-drag md-table-wrapper"><table class="no-header"><tbody><tr>Soil horizon letter designations</tr></tbody></table></div><div class="md-drag md-table-wrapper"><table class="no-header"><tbody><tr></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="md-drag md-table-wrapper"><table class="no-header"><tbody><tr><td colspan="2"><strong>Base symbols for surface horizons</strong></td></tr><tr><td>O</td><td>organic horizon containing litter and decomposed organic matter</td></tr><tr><td>A</td><td>mineral horizon darkened by humus accumulation</td></tr><tr>Base symbols for subsurface horizons</tr><tr><td>E</td><td>mineral horizon lighter in colour than an A or O horizon and depleted in clay minerals</td></tr><tr><td>AB or EB</td><td>transitional horizon more like A or E than B</td></tr><tr><td>BA or BE</td><td>transitional horizon more like B than A or E</td></tr><tr><td>B</td><td>accumulated clay and humus below the A or E horizon</td></tr><tr><td>BC or CB</td><td>transitional horizon from B to C</td></tr><tr><td>C</td><td>unconsolidated earth material below the A or B horizon</td></tr><tr><td>R</td><td>consolidated rock</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><strong>Suffixes added for special features of horizons</strong></td></tr><tr><td>a</td><td>highly decomposed organic matter</td></tr><tr><td>b</td><td>buried horizon</td></tr><tr><td>c</td><td>concretions or hard nodules (iron, aluminum, manganese, or titanium)</td></tr><tr><td>e</td><td>organic matter of intermediate decomposition</td></tr><tr><td>f</td><td>frozen soil</td></tr><tr><td>g</td><td>gray colour with strong mottling and poor drainage</td></tr><tr><td>h</td><td>accumulation of organic matter</td></tr><tr><td>i</td><td>slightly decomposed organic matter</td></tr><tr><td>k</td><td>accumulation of carbonate</td></tr><tr><td>m</td><td>cementation or induration</td></tr><tr><td>n</td><td>accumulation of sodium</td></tr><tr><td>o</td><td>accumulation of oxides of iron and aluminum</td></tr><tr><td>p</td><td>plowing or other anthropogenic disturbance</td></tr><tr><td>q</td><td>accumulation of silica</td></tr><tr><td>r</td><td>weathered or soft bedrock</td></tr><tr><td>s</td><td>accumulation of metal oxides and organic matter</td></tr><tr><td>t</td><td>accumulation of clay</td></tr><tr><td>v</td><td>plinthite (hard, iron-enriched subsoil material)</td></tr><tr><td>w</td><td>development of colour or structure</td></tr><tr><td>x</td><td>fragipan character (high-density, brittle)</td></tr><tr><td>y</td><td>accumulation of gypsum</td></tr><tr><td>z</td><td>accumulation of salts</td></tr></tbody></table></div></span><p>The combined A, E, B horizon sequence is called the <span id="ref705301"></span>solum (Latin: “floor”). The solum is the true seat of soil-forming processes and is the principal habitat for soil organisms. (Transitional layers, having intermediate properties, are designated with the two letters of the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/adjacent" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="adjacent">adjacent</a> horizons, as shown in the table of soil horizon letter designations.)</p><!--[P9]--><p>The second enhancement to soil horizon <span id="ref709152"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nomenclature" class="md-crosslink">nomenclature</a> (also shown in the <span id="ref2867"></span>table) is the use of lowercase suffixes to designate special features that are important to soil development. The most common of these suffixes are applied to B horizons: <em>g</em> to denote mottling caused by waterlogging, <em>h</em> to denote the illuvial accumulation of humus, <em>k</em> to denote <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/carbonate-mineral" class="md-crosslink autoxref">carbonate mineral</a> precipitates, <em>o</em> to denote residual metal oxides, <em>s</em> to denote the illuvial accumulation of metal oxides and humus, and <em>t</em> to denote the accumulation of clay.</p><!--[P10]--></section><section id="ref214836" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref705440"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/pedon" class="md-crosslink">Pedons</a> and <span id="ref705480"></span>polypedons</h2><p>Soils are natural elements of weathered landscapes whose properties may vary spatially. For scientific study, however, it is useful to think of soils as unions of modules known as pedons. A pedon is the smallest element of landscape that can be called soil. Its depth limit is the somewhat arbitrary boundary between soil and “not soil” (e.g., bedrock). Its lateral dimensions must be large enough to permit a study of any horizons present—in general, an area from 1 to 10 square metres (10 to 100 square feet), taking into account that a horizon may be variable in thickness or even discontinuous. Wherever horizons are cyclic and recur at intervals of 2 to 7 metres (7 to 23 feet), the pedon includes one-half the cycle. Thus, each pedon includes the range of horizon variability that occurs within small areas. Wherever the cycle is less than 2 metres, or wherever all horizons are continuous and of uniform thickness, the pedon has an area of 1 square metre.</p><!--[P11]--><p>Soils are encountered on the landscape as groups of similar pedons, called polypedons, that contain sufficient area to qualify as a taxonomic unit. Polypedons are bounded from below by “not soil” and laterally by pedons of dissimilar characteristics.</p><!--[P12]--></section></section><!--[H3]--><section id="ref214837" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1">Soil behaviour</h2><section id="ref214838" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Physical characteristics</h2><span id="ref214838" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref214839" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">Grain size and <span id="ref709146"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/porosity" class="md-crosslink">porosity</a></h2><p>The grain size of soil particles and the aggregate structures they form affect the ability of a soil to transport and retain water, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/air" class="md-crosslink autoxref">air</a>, and nutrients. Grain size is classified as <span id="ref705560"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-geology" class="md-crosslink">clay</a> if the particle diameter is less than 0.002 mm (0.0008 inch), as <span id="ref705780"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/silt" class="md-crosslink">silt</a> if it is between 0.002 mm (0.0008 inch) and 0.05 mm (0.002 inch), or as <span id="ref705541"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/sand" class="md-crosslink">sand</a> if it is between 0.05 mm (0.002 inch) and 2 mm (0.08 inch). <span id="ref709148"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/soil-texture" class="md-crosslink">Soil texture</a> refers to the relative proportions of sand, silt, and clay particle sizes, irrespective of chemical or <span id="ref709725"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/mineralogy" class="md-crosslink">mineralogical</a> composition (see the <span data-assembly-id="19382" class="md-link media-overlay-link">figure</span>). Sandy soils are called coarse-textured, and clay-rich soils are called fine-textured. Loam is a textural class representing about one-fifth clay, with sand and silt sharing the remainder equally.</p><!--[P13]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19382"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/21/24021-004-3F055051.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/21/24021-004-3F055051.jpg" alt="Soil texture as a function of the proportion of sand, silt, and clay particle sizes." data-width="349" data-height="310"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Soil texture as a function of the proportion of sand, silt, and clay particle sizes.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML13]--><p><span id="ref705500"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/pore-geology" class="md-crosslink">Pore</a> radii (space between soil particles) can range from millimetre-scale between sand grains to micrometre-scale between clay grains. Soil particles falling into the three principal size categories may have various mineralogical or chemical <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/compositions" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="compositions">compositions</a>, although sand particles often are composed of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/quartz" class="md-crosslink autoxref">quartz</a> and feldspars, silt particles often are micaceous, and clay particles often contain layer-type aluminosilicates (the so-called <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-mineral" class="md-crosslink">clay minerals</a>). Organic matter and <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/amorphous" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="amorphous">amorphous</a> <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/mineral-chemical-compound" class="md-crosslink autoxref">mineral</a> matter also are important <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/constituents" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="constituents">constituents</a> of soil clay particles.</p><!--[P14]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19571"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/88/24288-004-B94635D1.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/88/24288-004-B94635D1.jpg" alt="Microscopic view of an Inceptisol, showing small crystallites of carbonate minerals (around the central black void), quartz sand grains (white), and iron oxides and organic matter (dark brown)." data-width="433" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Microscopic view of an Inceptisol, showing small crystallites of carbonate minerals (around the central black void), quartz sand grains (white), and iron oxides and organic matter (dark brown).</span><cite>Hari Eswaran, USDA-NRCS</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML14]--><p>Porosity reflects the capacity of soil to hold air and water, and <span id="ref705820"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/permeability-geology" class="md-crosslink">permeability</a> describes the ease of transport of fluids and their dissolved components. The porosity of a soil horizon increases as its texture becomes finer, whereas the permeability decreases as the average pore size becomes smaller. Small pores not only restrict the passage of matter, but they also bring it into close proximity with chemical binding sites on the particle surface that can slow its movement. Clay and humus affect both soil porosity and permeability by binding soil grains together into <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/aggregates" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="aggregates">aggregates</a>, thereby creating a network of larger pores (macropores) that <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/facilitate" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="facilitate">facilitate</a> the movement of water. Plant roots open pores between soil aggregates, and cycles of wetting and drying create channels that allow water to pass easily. (However, this structure collapses under waterlogging conditions.) The stability of aggregates increases with humus content, especially humus that originates from grass vegetation. For soils that are not disturbed significantly by human activities, however, the pore space and the varieties of macropores are more important determinants of porosity than the soil texture. As a general rule, average pore size decreases from certain agricultural practices and other human uses of soil.</p><!--[P15]--></section><span id="ref214838" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref214840" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">Water <span id="ref706180"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/runoff" class="md-crosslink">runoff</a></h2><p>Aggregates of soil particles whose formation has not been influenced by human intervention are called <span id="ref705900"></span>peds. The peds in the surface horizons of soils develop into clods under the effects of cultivation and the traffic of urbanization. Soils whose A horizon is dense and unstructured increase the fraction of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/precipitation" class="md-crosslink autoxref">precipitation</a> that will become surface runoff and have a high potential for erosion and flooding. These soils include not only those whose peds have been degraded but also coarse-textured soils with low porosity, particularly those of arid regions.</p><!--[P16]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19383"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/22/24022-004-8EBB6780.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/22/24022-004-8EBB6780.jpg" alt="Soil profiles on hillslopesThe thickness and composition of soil horizons vary with position on a hillslope and with water drainage. For example, on the upper slopes of poorly drained profiles, underlying rock may be exposed by surface erosion, and nutrient-rich soils (A horizon) may accumulate at the toeslope. On the other hand, in well-drained profiles under forest cover, the leached layers (E horizon) may be relatively thick and surface erosion minimal." data-width="593" data-height="243"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Soil profiles on hillslopesThe thickness and composition of soil horizons vary with position on a hillslope and with water drainage. For example, on the upper slopes of poorly drained profiles, underlying rock may be exposed by surface erosion, and nutrient-rich soils (A horizon) may accumulate at the toeslope. On the other hand, in well-drained profiles under forest cover, the leached layers (E horizon) may be relatively thick and surface erosion minimal.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML16]--><p>A well-developed clay horizon (Bt) presents a deep-lying obstacle to the downward percolation of water. <span id="ref706260"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/subsurface-drainage" class="md-crosslink">Subsurface</a> runoff cannot easily penetrate the clay layer and flows laterally along the horizon as it moves toward the stream system. This type of runoff is slower than its erosive counterpart over the land surface and leads to water saturation of the upper part of the soil profile and the possibility of gravity-induced mass movement on hillslopes (e.g., landslides). It is also responsible for the translocation (migration) of dissolved products of chemical weathering down a hillslope sequence of related soil profiles (a toposequence). Subsurface water flow is also influenced by macropores, which, as noted above, are created through plant root growth and decay, animal burrowing activities, soil shrinkage while drying, or fracturing. In general, subsurface runoff processes are characteristic of soils in humid regions, whereas surface runoff is characteristic of arid regions and, of course, any landscape altered significantly by cultivation or urbanization.</p><!--[P17]--></section></section><section id="ref214841" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Chemical characteristics</h2><span id="ref214841" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref214842" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3">Mineral content</h2><p>The bulk of soil consists of mineral particles that are composed of arrays of <span id="ref709102"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/silicate-mineral" class="md-crosslink">silicate</a> <span id="ref706280"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/ion-physics" class="md-crosslink">ions</a> (SiO<sub>4</sub><sup>4−</sup>) combined with various positively charged metal ions. It is the number and type of the metal ions present that determine the particular mineral. The most common mineral found in the Earth’s crust is <span id="ref706240"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/feldspar" class="md-crosslink">feldspar</a>, an aluminosilicate that contains <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/sodium" class="md-crosslink autoxref">sodium</a>, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/potassium" class="md-crosslink autoxref">potassium</a>, or <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/calcium" class="md-crosslink autoxref">calcium</a> (sometimes called bases) in addition to aluminum ions. Weathering breaks up crystals of feldspars and other silicate minerals and releases chemical <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/compounds" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="compounds">compounds</a> such as bases, <span id="ref709106"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/silica" class="md-crosslink">silica</a>, and oxides of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/iron-chemical-element" class="md-crosslink autoxref">iron</a> and aluminum (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and <span id="ref706500"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/alumina" class="md-crosslink">alumina</a> [Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>]). After the bases are removed by <span id="ref706300"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/leaching-geochemistry-of-soil" class="md-crosslink">leaching</a>, the remaining silica and alumina combine to form <span id="ref709107"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/crystallization" class="md-crosslink">crystalline</a> clays.</p><!--[P18]--><p>The kind of crystalline clay produced depends on leaching intensity. Prolonged leaching leaves little silica to combine with alumina and results in what are known as 1:1 clays, consisting of alternating silica and alumina sheets; less extensive leaching leads to the formation of 2:1 clays, consisting of one alumina sheet sandwiched between two silica sheets. In neither case is the result solely one of the two types, though 1:1 clay is predominant in the tropics after prolonged leaching and 2:1 clay more abundant when leaching is less extensive in more temperate climates.</p><!--[P19]--><p>The solid soil particles are chemically reactive because of the presence of electrically charged sites on their surfaces. If a reactive site binds a dissolved ion or molecule to form a stable unit, a “surface complex” is said to exist. The formation reaction itself is called surface complexation. Surface complexation is an example of <span id="ref706600"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/adsorption" class="md-crosslink">adsorption</a>, a chemical process in which matter accumulates on a solid particle surface. Ions such as Ca<sup>2+</sup> (calcium), <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/magnesium" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Mg</a><sup>2+</sup> (magnesium), Na<sup>+</sup> (sodium), and NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> (nitrate) do not tend to adsorb strongly, making these important plant nutrients susceptible to easy replacement. Once ejected from their surface sites, these ions may be leached downward by percolating water to become removed from the biogeochemical cycles occurring in the upper part of the soil profile.</p><!--[P20]--><p><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Freshwater-England" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Freshwater</a> leaching of soils brings <span id="ref706620"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/hydrogen-ion" class="md-crosslink">hydrogen ions</a> (H<sup>+</sup>) that increase mineral solubility, releasing Al<sup>3+</sup> (aluminum), a toxic ion that can displace nutrients such as Ca<sup>2+</sup>. The gradual loss of nutrients and the accumulation of adsorbed H<sup>+</sup> and Al<sup>3+</sup> characterize the buildup of soil acidity, with its harmful effects on organisms. Soils display their acidity by a decrease in content of acid-soluble minerals (for example, feldspars or clay minerals) and an increase in insoluble minerals (iron and aluminum oxides). Soils weathered by freshwater leaching evolve from clay particles with a prevalence of metal ion-binding sites to highly weathered metal oxides that do not have sites that bind readily with metal ions.</p><!--[P21]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19552"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/69/24269-004-B762FFB8.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/69/24269-004-B762FFB8.jpg" alt="Ferralsol soil profile from Brazil, showing a deep red subsurface horizon resulting from accumulations of iron and aluminum oxides." data-width="200" data-height="398"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Ferralsol soil profile from Brazil, showing a deep red subsurface horizon resulting from accumulations of iron and aluminum oxides.</span><cite>© ISRIC, www.isric.nl</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML21]--></section><span id="ref214841" data-level="2"></span><section id="ref214843" data-level="3"><h2 class="h3"><span id="ref709109"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/organic-compound" class="md-crosslink">Organic</a> content</h2><p>The second major component of soils is organic matter produced by organisms. The total organic matter in soil, except for materials identifiable as undecomposed or partially decomposed biomass, is called <span id="ref709110"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/humus-soil-component" class="md-crosslink">humus</a>. This solid, dark-coloured component of soil plays a significant role in the control of soil acidity, in the cycling of nutrients, and in the detoxification of hazardous compounds. Humus consists of biological molecules such as proteins and carbohydrates as well as the humic substances (polymeric compounds produced through microbial action that differ from metabolically active compounds).</p><!--[P22]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19537"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/54/24254-004-8ADCC7F6.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/54/24254-004-8ADCC7F6.jpg" alt="Mollisol soil profile, showing a typically dark surface horizon rich in humus." data-width="200" data-height="376"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Mollisol soil profile, showing a typically dark surface horizon rich in humus.</span><cite>U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, Soil Survey Staff</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML22]--><p>The processes by which humus forms are not fully understood, but there is agreement that four stages of development occur in the transformation of soil biomass to humus: (1) decomposition of biomass into simple organic compounds, (2) metabolization of the simple compounds by microbes, (3) cycling of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and oxygen between soil organic matter and the microbial biomass, and (4) microbe-mediated polymerization of the cycled organic compounds.</p><!--[P23]--><p>The investigation of molecular structure in humic substances is a difficult area of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/electric-current" class="md-crosslink autoxref">current</a> research. Although it is not possible to describe the molecular configuration of humic substances in any but the most general terms, these molecules contain hydrogen ions that dissociate in fresh water to form molecules that bear a net negative charge. These negatively charged sites can interact with toxic metal ions and effectively remove them from further interaction with the <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/environment" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="environment">environment</a>.</p><!--[P24]--><p>Much of the molecular framework of soil organic matter, however, is not electrically charged. The uncharged portions of humic substances can react with <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/synthetic" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="synthetic">synthetic</a> organic compounds such as pesticides, fertilizers, solid and liquid waste materials, and their <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/degradation" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="degradation">degradation</a> products. Humus, either as a separate solid phase or as a coating on mineral surfaces, can immobilize these compounds and, in some instances, detoxify them significantly.</p><!--[P25]--></section></section><section id="ref214844" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2">Biological phenomena</h2><p>Fertile soils are biological <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/environments" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="environments">environments</a> teeming with life on all size scales, from <span id="ref706700"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/microfauna" class="md-crosslink">microfauna</a> (with body widths less than 0.1 mm [0.004 inch]) to <span id="ref706701"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/mesofauna" class="md-crosslink">mesofauna</a> (up to 2 mm [0.08 inch] wide) and <span id="ref706760"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/macrofauna" class="md-crosslink">macrofauna</a> (up to 20 mm [0.8 inch] wide). The most numerous soil organisms are the unicellular microfauna: 1 kilogram (2.2 pounds) of soil may contain 500 billion <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/bacteria" class="md-crosslink autoxref">bacteria</a>, 10 billion <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/actinomycete" class="md-crosslink">actinomycetes</a> (filamentous bacteria, some of which produce antibiotics), and nearly 1 billion fungi. The multicellular animal population can approach 500 million in a kilogram of soil, with microscopic <a href="https://www.britannica.com/animal/nematode" class="md-crosslink">nematodes</a> (roundworms) the most abundant. Mites and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/animal/springtail" class="md-crosslink">springtails</a>, which are categorized as mesofauna, are the next most prevalent. Earthworms, millipedes, centipedes, and insects make up most of the rest of the larger soil animal species. Plant roots also make a significant contribution to the biomass—the combined root length from a single plant can exceed 600 km (373 miles) in the top metre of a soil profile.</p><!--[P26]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19574"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/93/24293-004-D6FA503D.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/93/24293-004-D6FA503D.jpg" alt="Roundworm (nematode) hatching. Nematodes feed on bacteria, fungi, and small animal forms in the soil." data-width="300" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Roundworm (nematode) hatching. Nematodes feed on bacteria, fungi, and small animal forms in the soil.</span><cite>© Science Pictures Limited/Corbis</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML26]--><p>The soil flora and fauna play an important role in soil development. Microbiological activity in the rooting zone of soils is important to soil acidity and to the cycling of nutrients. Aerobic and anaerobic (oxygen-depleted) microniches support microbes that determine the rate of the production of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/carbon-dioxide" class="md-crosslink autoxref">carbon dioxide</a> (CO<sub>2</sub>) from organic matter or of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nitrate" class="md-crosslink autoxref">nitrate</a> (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>) from molecular nitrogen (N<sub>2</sub>).</p><!--[P27]--><p>The <span id="ref709647"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/carbon-cycle" class="md-crosslink">carbon</a> and <span id="ref709648"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nitrogen-cycle" class="md-crosslink">nitrogen</a> cycles are two important microbe-mediated cycles that are described in more detail in the section <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/soil/Soil-classification#ref214858" class="md-crosslink">Soils in ecosystems</a>. In this section, however, it is worth pointing out how they illustrate the complex, <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/integrated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="integrated">integrated</a> nature of a soil’s physical, chemical, and biological behaviour: soil peds and pore spaces provide microniches for the action of carbon- and nitrogen-cycling organisms, soil humus provides the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nutrient" class="md-crosslink autoxref">nutrient</a> reservoirs, and soil <span id="ref709649"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/biomass" class="md-crosslink">biomass</a> provides the chemical pathways for cycling. The carbon in dead biomass is converted to CO<sub>2</sub> by aerobic microorganisms and to organic acids or alcohols by anaerobic microorganisms. Under highly anaerobic conditions, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/methane" class="md-crosslink autoxref">methane</a> (CH<sub>4</sub>) is produced by bacteria. The CO<sub>2</sub> produced can be used by photosynthetic microorganisms or by higher plants to create new biomass and thus initiate the carbon cycle again.</p><!--[P28]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19381"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/20/24020-004-9A925367.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/20/24020-004-9A925367.jpg" alt="The carbon cycleCarbon is transported in various forms through the atmosphere, the hydrosphere, and geologic formations. One of the primary pathways for the exchange of carbon dioxide (CO2) takes place between the atmosphere and the oceans; there a fraction of the CO2 combines with water, forming carbonic acid (H2CO3) that subsequently loses hydrogen ions (H+) to form bicarbonate (HCO3−) and carbonate (CO32−) ions. Mollusk shells or mineral precipitates that form by the reaction of calcium or other metal ions with carbonate may become buried in geologic strata and eventually release CO2 through volcanic outgassing. Carbon dioxide also exchanges through photosynthesis in plants and through respiration in animals. Dead and decaying organic matter may ferment and release CO2 or methane (CH4) or may be incorporated into sedimentary rock, where it is converted to fossil fuels. Burning of hydrocarbon fuels returns CO2 and water (H2O) to the atmosphere. The biological and anthropogenic pathways are much faster than the geochemical pathways and, consequently, have a greater impact on the composition and temperature of the atmosphere." data-width="593" data-height="370"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">The carbon cycleCarbon is transported in various forms through the atmosphere, the hydrosphere, and geologic formations. One of the primary pathways for the exchange of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) takes place between the atmosphere and the oceans; there a fraction of the CO<sub>2</sub> combines with water, forming carbonic acid (H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) that subsequently loses hydrogen ions (H<sup>+</sup>) to form bicarbonate (HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>) and carbonate (CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup>) ions. Mollusk shells or mineral precipitates that form by the reaction of calcium or other metal ions with carbonate may become buried in geologic strata and eventually release CO<sub>2</sub> through volcanic outgassing. Carbon dioxide also exchanges through photosynthesis in plants and through respiration in animals. Dead and decaying organic matter may ferment and release CO<sub>2</sub> or methane (CH<sub>4</sub>) or may be incorporated into sedimentary rock, where it is converted to fossil fuels. Burning of hydrocarbon fuels returns CO<sub>2</sub> and water (H<sub>2</sub>O) to the atmosphere. The biological and anthropogenic pathways are much faster than the geochemical pathways and, consequently, have a greater impact on the composition and temperature of the atmosphere.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML28]--><p>The <span id="ref707000"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nitrogen" class="md-crosslink">nitrogen</a> (N) bound into proteins in dead biomass is consumed by microorganisms and converted into <span id="ref709645"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/ammonium-ion" class="md-crosslink">ammonium ions</a> (NH<sub>4</sub><sup>+</sup>) that can be directly absorbed by plant roots (for example, lowland rice). The ammonium ions are usually converted to nitrite ions (NO<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>) by <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nitrifying-bacterium" class="md-crosslink"><em>Nitrosomonas</em></a> bacteria, followed by a second conversion to nitrate (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>) by <em>Nitrobacter</em> bacteria. This very mobile form of nitrogen is that most commonly absorbed by plant roots, as well as by microorganisms in soil. To close the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/nitrogen-cycle" class="md-crosslink autoxref">nitrogen cycle</a>, nitrogen gas in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/atmosphere" class="md-crosslink autoxref">atmosphere</a> is converted to biomass nitrogen by <em>Rhizobium</em> bacteria living in the root tissues of legumes (e.g., alfalfa, peas, and beans) and leguminous trees (such as alder) and by cyanobacteria and <em>Azotobacter</em> bacteria.</p><!--[P29]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="6"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/37/6537-004-FC183C31.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/37/6537-004-FC183C31.jpg" alt="The nitrogen cycle." data-width="570" data-height="695"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">The nitrogen cycle.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML29]--></section></section><!--[H4]--><section id="ref214845" data-level="1"><h2 class="h1"><span id="ref709101"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/soil-formation" class="md-crosslink">Soil formation</a></h2><p>As stated at the beginning of this article, soils evolve under the action of biological, climatic, geologic, and topographic influences. The evolution of soils and their properties is called soil formation, and pedologists have identified five fundamental soil formation processes that influence soil properties. These five “state factors” are parent material, <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/topography" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="topography">topography</a>, climate, organisms, and time.</p><!--[P30]--><section id="ref214846" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref709650"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/parent-chemical-nomenclature" class="md-crosslink">Parent</a> material</h2><p>Parent material is the initial state of the solid matter making up a soil. It can consist of consolidated rocks, and it can also include unconsolidated deposits such as river <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/alluvium" class="md-crosslink autoxref">alluvium</a>, lake or marine sediments, glacial tills, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/loess" class="md-crosslink autoxref">loess</a> (silt-sized, wind-deposited particles), volcanic ash, and organic matter (such as accumulations in swamps or bogs). Parent materials influence soil formation through their mineralogical composition, their texture, and their stratification (occurrence in layers). Dark-coloured ferromagnesian (iron- and magnesium-containing) rocks, for example, can produce soils with a high content of iron compounds and of clay minerals in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-mineral#ref80128" class="md-crosslink">kaolin</a> or <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-mineral#ref80132" class="md-crosslink">smectite</a> groups, whereas light-coloured siliceous (silica-containing) rocks tend to produce soils that are low in iron compounds and that contain clay minerals in the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/illite" class="md-crosslink">illite</a> or <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-mineral#ref80131" class="md-crosslink">vermiculite</a> groups. The coarse texture of granitic rocks leads to a coarse, loamy soil texture and promotes the development of <span id="ref707020"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/E-horizon" class="md-crosslink">E horizons</a> (the leached lower regions of the topmost soil layer). The fine texture of basaltic rocks, on the other hand, yields soils with a <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/loam" class="md-crosslink autoxref">loam</a> or clay-loam texture and hinders the development of E horizons. Because water <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/percolates" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="percolates">percolates</a> to greater depths and drains more easily through soils with coarse texture, clearly defined E horizons tend to develop more fully on coarse parent material.</p><!--[P31]--><ul class="assemblies medialist" data-type="other"><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19558"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/75/24275-004-5E59528E.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/75/24275-004-5E59528E.jpg" alt="Leptosol soil profile from Switzerland, showing a typically shallow surface horizon with little evidence of soil formation." data-width="200" data-height="317"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Leptosol soil profile from Switzerland, showing a typically shallow surface horizon with little evidence of soil formation.</span><cite>© ISRIC, www.isric.nl</cite></figcaption></figure></li><li><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19553"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/70/24270-004-5D749430.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/70/24270-004-5D749430.jpg" alt="Fluvisol soil profile from South Africa, showing strata typical of sediments deposited from lakes, rivers, or oceans." data-width="248" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Fluvisol soil profile from South Africa, showing strata typical of sediments deposited from lakes, rivers, or oceans.</span><cite>© ISRIC, www.isric.nl</cite></figcaption></figure></li></ul><!--[ML31]--><p>In theory, parent material is either freshly exposed solid matter (for example, <span id="ref709517"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/volcanic-ash" class="md-crosslink">volcanic ash</a> immediately after ejection) or deep-lying geologic material that is isolated from atmospheric water and organisms. In practice, parent materials can be deposited continually by wind, water, or volcanoes and can be altered from their initial, isolated state, thereby making identification difficult. If a single parent material can be established for an entire soil profile, the soil is termed monogenetic; otherwise, it is polygenetic. An example of polygenetic soils are soils that form on sedimentary rocks or unconsolidated water- or wind-deposited materials. These so-called stratified parent materials can yield soils with intermixed geologic layering and soil horizons—as occurs in southeastern <span id="ref709677"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/England" class="md-crosslink">England</a>, where soils forming atop chalk bedrock layers are themselves overlain by soil layers formed on both loess and clay materials that have been modified by dissolution of the chalk below.</p><!--[P32]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19544"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/61/24261-004-325FEBFF.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/61/24261-004-325FEBFF.jpg" alt="Andosol soil profile from Italy, showing a dark-coloured surface horizon derived from volcanic parent material." data-width="200" data-height="438"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Andosol soil profile from Italy, showing a dark-coloured surface horizon derived from volcanic parent material.</span><cite>© ISRIC, www.isric.nl</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML32]--><p>Adjacent soils frequently exhibit different profile characteristics because of differing parent materials. These differing soil areas are called <span id="ref709681"></span>lithosequences, and they fall into two general types. Continuous lithosequences have parent materials whose properties vary gradually along a transect, the prototypical example being soils formed on loess deposits at increasing distances downwind from their alluvial source. Areas of such deposits in the central <span id="ref709678"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/United-States" class="md-crosslink">United States</a> or <span id="ref709679"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/China" class="md-crosslink">China</a> show systematic decreases in particle size and rate of deposition with increasing distance from the source. As a result, they also show increases in clay content and in the extent of profile development from weathering of the loess particles.</p><!--[P33]--><p>By contrast, discontinuous lithosequences arise from abrupt changes in parent material. A simple example might be one soil formed on schist (a silicate-containing <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/metamorphic-rock" class="md-crosslink autoxref">metamorphic rock</a> rich in mica) <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/juxtaposed" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="juxtaposed">juxtaposed</a> with a soil formed on serpentine (a ferromagnesian metamorphic rock rich in olivine). More subtle discontinuous lithosequences, such as those on glacial tills, show systematic variation of mineralogical composition or of texture in unconsolidated parent materials.</p><!--[P34]--></section><section id="ref214847" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref709416"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/topography-geology" class="md-crosslink">Topography</a></h2><p>Topography, when considered as a soil-forming factor, includes the following: the geologic structural characteristics of elevation above mean <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/sea-level" class="md-crosslink autoxref">sea level</a>, aspect (the compass orientation of a landform), slope configuration (i.e., either convex or concave), and relative position on a slope (that is, from the toe to the summit). Topography influences the way the <span id="ref709683"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/water-cycle" class="md-crosslink">hydrologic cycle</a> affects earth material, principally with respect to <span id="ref709682"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/runoff" class="md-crosslink">runoff</a> processes and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/evapotranspiration" class="md-crosslink autoxref">evapotranspiration</a>. Precipitation may run off the land surface, causing soil erosion, or it may <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/percolate" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="percolate">percolate</a> into soil profiles and become part of subsurface runoff, which eventually makes its way into the stream system. Erosive runoff is most likely on a convex slope just below the summit, whereas lateral subsurface runoff tends to cause an accumulation of soluble or suspended matter near the toeslope. The conversion of precipitation into evapotranspiration is favoured by lower elevation and an equatorially facing aspect.</p><!--[P35]--><p>Adjacent soils that show differing profile characteristics reflecting the influence of local topography are called <span id="ref709684"></span>toposequences. As a general rule, soil profiles on the convex upper slopes in a toposequence are more shallow and have less distinct subsurface horizons than soils at the summit or on lower, concave-upward slopes. Organic matter content tends to increase from the summit down to the toeslope, as do clay content and the concentrations of soluble compounds.</p><!--[P36]--><p>Often the dominant effect of topography is on subsurface runoff (or <span id="ref709415"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/drainage-basin" class="md-crosslink">drainage</a>). In humid temperate regions, well-drained soil profiles near a summit can have thick E horizons (the leached layers) overlying well-developed clay-rich Bt horizons, while poorly drained profiles near a toeslope can have thick A horizons overlying extensive Bg horizons (lower layers whose pale colour signals stagnation under water-saturated conditions). In humid tropical regions with dry seasons, these profile characteristics give way to less distinct horizons, with accumulation of silica, <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/manganese" class="md-crosslink autoxref">manganese</a>, and iron near the toeslope, whereas in semiarid regions soils near the toeslope have accumulations of the soluble salts <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/salt" class="md-crosslink autoxref">sodium chloride</a> or calcium <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/sulfate" class="md-crosslink autoxref">sulfate</a>.</p><!--[P37]--><p>These general conclusions are tempered by the fact that topography is susceptible to great changes over time. Soil erosion by water or wind removes A horizons and exposes B horizons to weathering. Major portions of entire soil profiles can move downslope suddenly by the combined action of water and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/gravity-physics" class="md-crosslink autoxref">gravity</a>. Catastrophic natural events, such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, and devastating storms, can have obvious consequences for the instability of geomorphologic patterns.</p><!--[P38]--></section><section id="ref214848" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref709398"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/climate-meteorology" class="md-crosslink">Climate</a></h2><p>The term <em>climate</em> in <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/pedology" class="md-crosslink autoxref">pedology</a> refers to the characteristics of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/weather" class="md-crosslink autoxref">weather</a> as they evolve over time scales longer than those necessary for soil properties to develop. These characteristics include precipitation, temperature, and storm patterns—both their averages and their variation.</p><!--[P39]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19550"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/67/24267-004-006DD27F.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/67/24267-004-006DD27F.jpg" alt="Cryosol soil profile from Canada showing patterned deformations caused by cycles of freeze and thaw." data-width="266" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Cryosol soil profile from Canada showing patterned deformations caused by cycles of freeze and thaw.</span><cite>© ISRIC, www.isric.nl</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML39]--><p>Climate influences soil formation primarily through effects of <span id="ref709685"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/water" class="md-crosslink">water</a> and <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/solar-energy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">solar energy</a>. Water is the solvent in which chemical reactions take place in the soil, and it is essential to the life cycles of soil organisms. Water is also the principal medium for the erosive or percolative transport of solid particles. The rates at which these water-mediated processes take place are controlled by the amount of <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/energy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">energy</a> available from the sun.</p><!--[P40]--><p>On a global scale, the integrated effects of climate can readily be seen along a transect from pole to <a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Equator" class="md-crosslink autoxref">Equator</a>. As one proceeds from the pole to cool tundra or forested regions, polar <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/desert" class="md-crosslink autoxref">desert</a> soils give way to intensively leached soils such as the <span id="ref709142"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/Podzol" class="md-crosslink">Podzols</a> (Spodosols) that exhibit an eye-catching, ash-coloured E horizon indicative of humid, boreal climates. Farther into temperate zones, organic matter accumulates in soils as climates become warmer, and eventually lime (calcium carbonate) also begins to accumulate closer to the top of the soil profile as evapotranspiration increases. Arid subtropical climate then follows, with desert soils that are low in organic matter and enriched in soluble salts. As the climate again becomes humid close to the Equator, high temperature combines with high precipitation to create red and yellow tropical soils, whose colours reveal the prevalence of residual iron oxide minerals that are resistant to leaching losses because of their low solubility.</p><!--[P41]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19384"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/23/24023-004-EB638788.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/23/24023-004-EB638788.jpg" alt="The effects of climate on soil worldwideA schematic cross section of the Earth illustrates the variation in soil types arising from differences in climate from the North Pole to the Equator." data-width="465" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">The effects of climate on soil worldwideA schematic cross section of the Earth illustrates the variation in soil types arising from differences in climate from the North Pole to the Equator.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML41]--><p>On a continental scale, a transect taken across the central United States from east to west shows the effects of increasing evapotranspiration. First, soils that exhibit E horizons appear, followed by soils high in organic matter. These give way to soils with accumulations of lime and ultimately to desert soils with soluble <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/salt-acid-base-reactions" class="md-crosslink autoxref">salt</a> efflorescence (powdery crust) near the surface.</p><!--[P42]--><p>On a regional scale, variations in climate also can influence soil properties significantly, resulting in a <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/contiguous" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="contiguous">contiguous</a> array of soils called a <span id="ref709686"></span>climosequence. One typical climosequence occurs along a 1,000-km (600-mile) north-south transect through the foothills of the Cascade and Sierra Nevada mountains in California. There soils that have formed on landscapes of similar topography vary continuously in their profile characteristics with variations in annual precipitation. Soils formed at the dry southern end of the transect are shallow and rocky, whereas those at the humid northern end show well-developed B horizons and reddish colour. Clay <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/mineralogy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">mineralogy</a> in the upper 20 cm (8 inches) of these soils also responds to the increase in precipitation, shifting from the smectite group to the mixed vermiculite or illite group/kaolin group and finally to the kaolin group alone. These changes result primarily from increasing loss of silica and soluble metals as soil leaching extends deeper with increasing rainfall. In addition, soil acidity and organic matter content increase, while readily soluble forms of calcium (important to plant growth and soil aggregation) decrease, with increasing precipitation.</p><!--[P43]--><p>In principle, soil profile characteristics that are closely linked to climate can in turn be interpreted as climatic indicators. For example, a soil profile with two well-defined zones of lime accumulation, one shallow and one deep, may signal the existence of a past climate whose greater precipitation drove the lime layer deeper than the present climate is able to do.</p><!--[P44]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19385"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/24/24024-004-4C3E75C2.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/24/24024-004-4C3E75C2.jpg" alt="Depth to lime accumulation in relation to annual rainfall  Lime (CaCO3) deposits that can prevent the penetration of plant roots are found deeper in the soil profile in climates with higher mean annual rainfall than in climates where there is little water to transport the lime through the soil." data-width="533" data-height="300"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Depth to lime accumulation in relation to annual rainfall  Lime (CaCO<sub>3</sub>) deposits that can prevent the penetration of plant roots are found deeper in the soil profile in climates with higher mean annual rainfall than in climates where there is little water to transport the lime through the soil.</span><cite>Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML44]--><p>Soils that formed in past environments different from the present and that are preserved (at least partially) at greater depth are known as <span id="ref709687"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/paleosol" class="md-crosslink">paleosols</a>. Some features of these soils can serve as climatic indicators, the most reliable being <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/robust" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="robust">robust</a> features such as horizons with hardened accumulations of relatively insoluble iron, manganese, or calcium minerals or layers with accumulations of strongly <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/aggregated" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="aggregated">aggregated</a> clay-size particles. Given a knowledge of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-mineral" class="md-crosslink autoxref">clay mineral</a> in a suspected paleosol, and assuming the precipitation-clay mineralogy relationship described above, pedologists might be able to infer past climate. The precipitation level of a past climate might be inferred from an observation of the depth of lime-containing horizons in a paleosol. These potential applications of climatic relationships must be evaluated carefully in order to distinguish the effects of previously weathered parent material from those of purely climatic influence.</p><!--[P45]--></section><section id="ref214849" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref709417"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/soil-organism" class="md-crosslink">Organisms</a></h2><p>The development of soils can be significantly affected by vegetation, animal inhabitants, and human populations. Any array of contiguous soils influenced by local flora and fauna is termed a <span id="ref709702"></span>biosequence. To return to the climosequence along the <span id="ref709700"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Cascade-Range" class="md-crosslink">Cascade</a> and <span id="ref709701"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Sierra-Nevada-mountains" class="md-crosslink">Sierra Nevada</a> ranges discussed above, the vegetation observed along this narrow foothill <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/region-geography" class="md-crosslink autoxref">region</a> varies from shrubs in the dry south to needle-leaved trees in the humid north, with extensive <span id="ref709477"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/grassland" class="md-crosslink">grasslands</a> in between. In the middle of the precipitation range, transition zones occur in which small groves of needle-leaved trees are interspersed with grassland patches in an apparently random manner. These plant populations represent local flora largely selected by climate. The properties of the soils underlying these plants, however, exhibit differences that do not arise from climate, topography, or parent material but are an effect of the differing plant species. The soils under trees, for instance, are much more acidic and contain much less humus than those under grass, and nitrogen content is considerably greater in the grassland soil. These properties come directly from the type of litter produced by the two different kinds of vegetation.</p><!--[P46]--><p>An opportunity to examine biosequences is often presented by relatively young soils formed from an alluvial parent material. Soils of this kind lying beneath shrubs may be richer in humus and plant nutrients than similar soils found beneath needle-leaved trees. This variation results from differences in the cyclic processes of plant growth, litter production, and litter decay. Organic matter decomposers will feed on stored material in soil if litter production is low, whereas high litter production will permit soil stocks of organic matter to increase, leading to humus-rich A horizons as opposed to the leached E horizons found in soils that form under humid climatic conditions.</p><!--[P47]--><p>Human beings are also part of the biological influx that influences soil formation. Human influence can be as severe as wholesale removal or burial (by urbanization) of an entire soil profile, or it can be as subtle as a gradual modification of organic matter by agriculture or of soil structure by irrigation. The chemical and physical properties of soils critical to the growth of crops often are affected significantly by cultural practices. Among the problems created for agriculture by cultural practices themselves are loss of arable land, erosion, the buildup of salinity, and the depletion of organic matter.</p><!--[P48]--><div class="assemblies"><figure data-type="image" class="md-assembly  media-overlay-link print-false" data-assembly-id="19545"><div class="md-assembly-wrapper" data-type="image"><div class="image-wrapper mg"><img src="https://cdn.britannica.com/700x450/62/24262-004-7A98C871.jpg" big-src="https://cdn.britannica.com/62/24262-004-7A98C871.jpg" alt="Anthrosol soil profile from The Netherlands, showing surface layers made homogeneous through human activity." data-width="200" data-height="405"></div></div><figcaption><span class="md-assembly-caption">Anthrosol soil profile from The Netherlands, showing surface layers made homogeneous through human activity.</span><cite>© ISRIC, www.isric.nl</cite></figcaption></figure></div><!--[ML48]--></section><section id="ref214850" data-level="2"><h2 class="h2"><span id="ref709703"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/time" class="md-crosslink">Time</a></h2><p>The soil-forming factors of parent material and topography are largely site-related (attributes of the terrain), whereas those of climate and organisms are largely flux-related (inputs from the surroundings). Time as a soil-forming factor is neither a property of the terrain nor a source of external stimulus. It is instead an abstract variable whose significance is solely as a marker of the evolution of soil characteristics. The <a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/conceptual" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="conceptual">conceptual</a> independence of time from its four companion factors means simply that soil evolution can occur while site attributes and external inputs remain essentially unchanged.</p><!--[P49]--><p>Certain soil profile features can be interpreted as indicators of the passage of time. (A series of soil profiles whose features differ only as a result of age constitutes a chronosequence.) One example of a time-related feature is the humus content of the <span id="ref709704"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/A-horizon" class="md-crosslink">A horizon</a>, which, for soils less than 10,000 years old, increases continually at a rate dependent on parent material, vegetation, and climate. Typically, this rate of increase slows after about 10,000 years, plant nutrients begin to leach away, and a significant decline in humus content is observed for soils whose age approaches one million years. (Agricultural practices can interrupt this trend, causing a gradual drop in stored humus by 25 percent or more. Correlated with these changes are economically important soil properties, such as nutrient supply and retention capability, acidity, and aeration.)</p><!--[P50]--><p>The accumulation of <span id="ref709705"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-geology" class="md-crosslink">clay</a> and <span id="ref709706"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/calcium-oxide" class="md-crosslink">lime</a> in soil profiles as a result of their translocation downward is also an indication of aging. For example, older soils that have formed on calcium-containing loess deposits have better-developed E and Bt horizons (as well as thinner A horizons) than younger soils forming on these deposits. Similarly, soils in a chronosequence developed on alluvium can exhibit a clayey <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/calcrete" class="md-crosslink autoxref">hardpan</a> after 100,000 years or so. Soils also tend to redden in colour as they age, irrespective of climatic conditions, reflecting the persistence of poorly crystalline or crystalline oxide minerals containing Fe<sup>3+</sup>. Indeed, the dominant mineralogy of the clay-size particles in soils is itself a reliable indicator of soil age. Any particular sequence of predominant <a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/clay-mineralogy" class="md-crosslink autoxref">clay mineralogy</a> found in a soil is known collectively as the set of <span id="ref709723"></span>Jackson-Sherman weathering stages (see the <span id="ref2861"></span>table). Each downward increment through the table corresponds to increasing mineral residence time, both among and within the three principal stages (early, intermediate, and advanced).</p><!--[P51]--><span class="md-raw-html"><div class="md-drag md-table-wrapper"><table class="no-header"><tbody><tr><td colspan="4"><p><span style="font-size:1.1em"><strong>Jackson-Sherman soil weathering stages</strong></span></p></td></tr><tr><td> </td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">characteristic minerals in soil clay fraction</span></p></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">characteristic chemical and physical conditions of soil</span></p></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">characteristic soil profile features</span></p></td></tr><tr><td><span style="font-size:1.1em">early stage</span></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">gypsum, carbonates, olivine/pyroxene/ amphibole, Fe<sup>2+</sup>-bearing micas, and feldspars</span></p></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">low water and humus content, limited leaching, reducing environments, and limited time for weathering</span></p></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">minimally weathered soils all over the world, though mainly in arid regions, where low rainfall keeps weathering to a minimum</span></p></td></tr><tr><td><span style="font-size:1.1em">intermediate stage</span></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">quartz, mica/illite, vermiculite/chlorite, and smectite</span></p></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">retention of Na, K, Ca, Mg, Fe<sup>2+</sup>, and silica; alkalinity<br>and ineffective leaching; igneous rock rich in Ca, Mg, and Fe<sup>2+</sup> but no Fe<sup>2+</sup> oxides; easily hydrolyzed silicates; and transport of silica into <br>the weathering zone</span></p></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">soils of temperate regions developed under grass or<br>trees--i.e., the major agricultural soils of the <br>world</span></p></td></tr><tr><td><span style="font-size:1.1em">advanced stage</span></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">kaolin, aluminum and <br>iron oxides, and titanium oxides</span></p></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">removal of Na, K, Ca, Mg, Fe<sup>2+</sup>, and silica; effective leaching by fresh water; low pH; and dispersion of silica</span></p></td><td><p><span style="font-size:1.1em">intensely weathered soils of the humid tropics, frequently characterized by acidity and low fertility</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></span><p>The early stage of <span id="ref709724"></span><a href="https://www.britannica.com/science/weathering-geology" class="md-crosslink">weathering</a> is recognized through the dominance of sulfates, carbonates, and primary silicates, other than quartz and muscovite, in the soil clay fraction. These minerals can survive only if soils remain very dry, very cold, or very wet most of the time—that is, if they have limited exposure to water, air, or solar energy. The intermediate stage features quartz, muscovite, and secondary aluminosilicates prominently in the clay fraction. These minerals can survive under leaching conditions that do not deplete silica and metals, such as calcium or magnesium, and that do not result in the complete oxidation of Fe<sup>2+</sup>, which is then incorporated into illite and smectite clays. The advanced stage, on the other hand, is associated with intensive leaching and strong oxidizing conditions, such that only oxides of aluminum, Fe<sup>3+</sup>, and titanium remain. Kaolin will be a dominant clay mineral group only if the removal of silica by leaching is not complete or if there is an encroachment of silica-rich waters—as can occur, for example, when water percolating through a soil profile at the upper part of a toposequence moves downslope into a soil profile at the lower part.</p><!--[P52]--><p><a href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/Implicit" class="md-dictionary-link" data-term="Implicit">Implicit</a> is the conclusion that more time is required to form soils featuring the more persistent minerals in the clay fraction. This conclusion is borne out by careful field studies worldwide in which the rate of soil horizon formation is determined. Soils whose clay mineralogy falls in the early stage require less than a decade to develop a centimetre (0.4 inch) of horizon thickness. Soils with dominant clay minerals in the intermediate stage do this in less than a century, whereas soils with dominant clay minerals in the advanced stage need several hundred years to form a centimetre of solum.</p><!--[P53]--></section></section><nav class="prev-next-pagination margin-top-50 margin-bottom-50 grid no-gutter  has-next">        <div class="pagination-control
